IBI GROUP FINAL REPORT
HUMBERTOWN SECONDARY PLAN AREA STUDY - PHASE 1: SUMMARY OF FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
Prepared for City of Toronto




Appendix A – Excerpts from the Toronto
Official Plan (Consolidated December 2010)
Note: Appendix A contains excerpts from the Toronto Official Plan which are most relevant to the Humbertown Secondary Plan Study Area.
While the Plan is organized into various chapters and sections, it is a comprehensive and cohesive whole and should be read in its entirety.
A full version of the Toronto Official Plan can be found on the City’s website:
www1.toronto.ca/static_files/CityPlanning/PDF/chapters1_5_dec2010.pdf.

                                                                          LAND USE DESIGNATIONS




  8. Zoning by-laws will contain numerical site standards for matters such as
     building type and height. density, lot sizes, lot depths, lot frontages, parking,
     building setbacks from lot lines, landscaped open space and any other
     performance standards to ensure that new development will be compatible
     with the physical character of established residential Neighbourhoods.

  9. lnfill development on properties that vary from the local pattern in terms of lot
     size, configuration and/or orientation in established Neighbourhoods will:
       a) have heights, massing and scale appropriate for the site and compatible
          with that permitted by the zoning for adjacent and nearby residential
          properties;
       b) provide adequate privacy, sunlight and sky views for residents of new
          and existing buildings by ensuring adequate distance and separation
          between building walls and using landscaping, planting and fencing to
          enhance privacy where needed;
       c) front onto existing or newly created public streets wherever possible, with
          no gates limiting public access; and
       d) locate and screen service areas and garbage storage to minimize the
          impact on existing and new streets and residences.

  10. Where development is proposed on a site with an existing apartment
      building in Neighbourhoods, the new development must be grade-related
      and must also meet the criteria regarding infill development in Apartment
      Neighbourhoods.




4.2   APARTMENT NEIGHBOURHOODS
      Rental apartment and condominium buildings already contain
      almost half of the dwelling units in Toronto at the millennium.
      Many of these buildings are clustered in areas already developed
      as apartment neighbourhoods. ln these established Apartment
      Neighbourhoods, improving amenities, accommodating sensitive
      inflll, where it can improve the quality of life and promoting
      environmental sustainability are key considerations. Residents
      in Apartment Neighbourhoods should have a high quality urban
      environment, safety, quality services and residential amenities.

      Apartment Neighbourhoods are distinguished from low-rise
      Neighbourhoods because a greater scale of buildings is permitted
      and different scale-related criteria are needed to guide development.
      Built up Apartment Neighbourhoods are stable areas of the City
      where signiflcant growth is generally not anticipated. There may,
      however, be opportunities for additional townhouses or apartments
      on underutilized sites and this Plan sets out criteria to evaluate
      these situations.




                                                               l!IROtllQ. n _ ••
                                                                            I'                    4-5
      LAND USE DESIGNATIONS




          Policies
          1. Apartment Neighbourhoods are made up of apartment buildings and parks,
             local institutions, cultural and recreational facilities, and small-scale retail,
             service and office uses that serve the needs of area residents. All land
             uses provided for in the Neighbourhoods designation are also permitted in
             Apartment Neighbourhoods.


          Development Criteria in Apartment Neighbourhoods

          2. Development in Apartment Neighbourhoods will contribute to the quality of
             life by:
                a) locating and massing new buildings to provide a transition between
                   areas of different development intensity and scale, as necessary to
                   achieve the objectives of this Plan, tlirough means such as providing
                   setbacks from, and/or a stepping down of heights towards, lower-scale
                   Neighbourhoods;
                b) locating and massing new buildings so as to adequately limit shadow
                   impacts on properties in adjacent lower-scale Neighbourhoods,
                   particularly during the spring and fall equinoxes;
                c) locating and massing new buildings to frame the edge of streets and
                   parks with good proportion and maintain sunlight and comfortable wind
                   conditions for pedestrians on adjacent streets, parks and open spaces;
                d) including sufficient off-street motor vehicle and bicycle parking for
                   residents and visitors;
                e) locating and screening service areas, ramps and garbage storage to
                   minimize the impact on adjacent streets and residences;
                n  providing indoor and outdoor recreation space for building residents in
                   every significant multi-unit residential development;
                g) providing ground floor uses that enhance the safety, amenity and
                   animation of adjacent streets and open spaces; and
                h) providing buildings that conform to the principles of universal design,
                   and wherever possible contain units that are accessible or adaptable for
                   persons with physical disabilities.

          3. Significant growth is generally not intended within developed Apartment
             Neighbourhoods. However, compatible infill development may be permitted
             on a site containing an existing apartment that has sufficient underutilized
             space to accommodate one or more new buildings while providing good
             quality of life for both new and existing reSidents. lnfill development that may
             be permitted on a site containing an existing apartment building will:
                a) meet the development criteria set out in Section 4.2.2 for apartments;
                b) maintain an appropriate level of residential amenity on the site;
                c) provide existing residents with access to the community benefits where
                   additional height and/or density is permitted and community benefits are
                   provided pursuant to Section 5.1.1 of this Plan;
                d) maintain adequate sunlight. privacy and areas of landscaped open space
                   for both new and existing residents;
                e) organize development on the site to frame streets, parks and open
                   spaces in good proportion, provide adequate sky views from the public
                   realm, and create safe and comfortable open spaces;

4-6                           . ,.
                                                                          LAND USE DESIGNATIONS




      f) front onto and provide pedestrian entrances from an adjacent public
         street wherever possible;
      g) provide adequate on-site, below grade, shared vehicular parking for both
         new and existing development, with any surface parking appropriately
         screened;
      h) preserve and/or replace important landscape features and walkways and
         create such features where they did not previously exist;
      i) consolidate loading, servicing and delivery facilities; and
     j) preserve or provide adequate alternative on-site recreational space for
         residents.




4J   PAHKS AND OPFN SPACE AREAS
     Toronto's many parks and open spaces offer residents, workers
     and visitors a range of experiences - everything from the extensive
     urban wilderness of the Rouge Park to the urbanity and intimacy
     of the community parks that are scattered throughout the city's
     neighbourhoods. The Parks and Open Space Areas in our city are
     the places where we can take a break from the bustle of city life,
     participate in a sporting activity, or play an informal game of frisbee
     with friends on a Sunday afternoon. They contain many of the City's
     natural habitat areas, recreation trails, stormwater management
     facilities and include some privately owned lands which adjoin a
     ravine or the waterfront.



 Policies
 1. Parks and Open Space Areas are the parks and open spaces, valleys,
    watercourses and ravines, portions of the waterfront. golf courses and
    cemeteries that comprise a green open space network in Toronto. They
    comprise the areas shown on Maps 13-23 shown as Natural Areas, Parks
    and Other Open Space Areas.

 2. Development is generally prohibited within Parks and Open Space Areas
    except for recreational and cultural facilities, conservation projects, cemetery
                                                                                                     ...
    facilities, public transit and essential public works and utilities where
    supported by appropriate assessment. Hydro uses will have primacy of use
    on those lands identified as hydro corridors on Maps 13-23.

 3. The areas shown as Natural Areas on Maps 13-23 will be maintained
    primarily in a natural state, while allowing for:
      a) compatible recreational, cultural and educational uses and facilities that
         minimize adverse impacts on natural features and functions; and
      b) conservation projects, public transit, public works and utilities for which
         no reasonable alternatives are available, and that are designed to have
         only minimal adverse impacts on natural features and functions.

                    Mixed Use Areas achieve a multitude of planning objectives by
                    combining a broad array of residential uses, offices, retail and
                    services, institutions, entertainment, recreation and cultural
                    activities, and parks and open spaces. Torontonians will be able to
                    live, work, and shop in the same area, or even the same building,
                    giving people an opportunity to depend less on their cars, and
                    create districts along transit routes that are animated, attractive and
                    safe at all hours of the day and night.

                    Mixed Use Areas will absorb most of the anticipated increase in retail,
                    office and service employment in Toronto in the coming decades,
                    as well as much of the new housing. The proportion of commercial
                    and residential uses will vary widely among Mixed Use Areas. For
                    example, office and retail uses will continue to be paramount in
                    the Financial District, but much of the new development along the
                    Avenues will have a residential emphasis.

                    Not all Mixed Use Areas will experience the same scale or intensity
                    of development. The highest buildings and greatest intensity will
                    typically occur Downtown, particularly in the Financial District. The
                    Centres will develop at differing scales and densities, set out in
                    their respective Secondary Plans and zoning by-laws, reflecting the
                    context of their surroundings and transportation infrastructure.
                    Development along the Avenues will generally be at a much lower
                    scale than in the Downtown and most often at a lower scale than
                    in the Centres.



                Policies
                1. Mixed Use Areas are made up of a broad range of commercial, residential
                     and institutional uses, in single use or mixed use buildings, as well as parks
                     and open spaces and utilities.


               Development Criteria in Mixed Use Areas

               2. In Mixed Use Areas development will:
                     a) create a balance of high quality commercial, residential. institutional and
                        open space uses that reduces automobile dependency and meets the
                        needs of the local community;
                     b) provide for new jobs and homes for Toronto's growing population on
                        underutilized lands in the Downtown, the Central Waterfront, Centres,
                        Avenues and other lands designated Mixed Use Areas, creating and
                        sustaining well-paid, stable, safe and fulfilling employment opportunities
                        for all Torontonians;



       lOHQ! IQ
4-10
                            1       L • I"
                                                                           LAND USE DESIGNATIONS




      · c) locate and mass new buildings to provide a transition between areas of
            different development intensity and scale, as necessary to achieve the
            objectives of this Plan, through means such as providing appropriate
            setbacks and/or a stepping down of heights, particularly towards lower
            scale Neighbourhoods;
         d) locate and mass new buildings so as to adequately limit shadow impacts
            on adjacent Neighbourhoods, particularly during the spring and fall
            equinoxes;
         e) locate and mass new buildings to frame the edges of streets and
            parks with good proportion and maintain sunlight and comfortable wind
            conditions for pedestrians on adjacent streets, parks and open spaces;
         0 provide an attractive, comfortable and safe pedestrian environment;
         g) have access to schools, parks, community centres, libraries, and
            childcare;
         h) take advantage of nearby transit services;
         i) provide good site access and circulation and an adequate supply of
            parking for residents and visitors;
        j) locate and screen service areas, ramps and garbage storage to minimize
            the impact on adjacent streets and residences; and
         k) provide indoor and outdoor recreation space for building residents in
            every significant multi-unit residential development.

  3. Large scale, stand-alone retail stores and/or "power centres" are not
     permitted in Mixed Use Areas within the Central Waterfront. and Downtown,
     and are permitted only through a zoning by-law amendment in other Mixed
     Use Areas. Where permitted new large scale, stand-alone retail stores and/
     or "power centres" will ensure that:
        a) sufficient transportation capacity is available to accommodate the
           additional traffic generated by the development, resulting in an acceptable
           volume of traffic on adjacent and nearby streets; and
        b) the function and amenity of the area for businesses and residents and
           the economic health of nearby shopping districts are not adversely
           affected_

  4. Existing large scale, stand-alone retail stores and/or "power centres" legally
     established prior to the approval date of this Official Plan in Mixed Use Areas
     are permitted.




4.6     EMPLOYMENT AREAS
       Toronto's Employment Areas are the hothouses where we grow our
       enterprises and jobs.

       Businesses increasingly require flexibility in order to compete
       effectively in the global economy. This need for flexibility extends
       to a ftrm's lands and buildings, and to what is available to support
       that business activity in the immediate area. A broad and inclusive


                                                                muomo_,.                           4-11
                                                           !.!!l~.LEMENTAfJ9.N.' .tot~KING JHJ~~S .HAPPEfi




        • Secondary Planning Areas - localized policies setting the stage
          for growth in an area;
        • Community Improvement Project Areas - promoting public and
          private investment in areas of need; and
        • Development Permit Areas - streamlining approvals and
          customizing local planning rules.

        These approaches are "tool boxes", offering a variety of mechanisms
        suited to different local challenges. To optimize adaptability and
        effectiveness in local situations, these approaches can be used
        individually, in combination with each other, or in conjunction
        with a range of other planning tools. They are also critical for
        implementing the City structure directions throughout this Plan
        and particularly in Chapter Two (e.g. Centres, Avenues).



s.2.1   SECONDARY PLANS: POLICIES FOR
        LOCAL GROWTH OPPORTUNITIES
        Secondary Plans establish local development policies to guide growth
        and change in a defined area of the City. The Plans will not be
        prepared for stable areaS Of the City, where major physical Change iS                                Secondary Plans set the stage for physical growth
        not expected or desired . Secondary Plans guide the creat ion of ri ew                               and improvement
        neighbo urh oods and empl oyment districts while ensuring adequate
        publ ic infrastructure and environm enta l protection. econd ary Plan
        policie adapt and impl ement the objective , policies, land use
        desig11ations and overall planning ap proach of t he Official 'Plan to fit
        local contexts and are adopted as amendments to the Oftlcial Plan.

        This Plan contains a number of Secondary Plans approved as part
        of the Official Plans of the former municipalities. A number of these
        historic Secondary Plans have been kept in whole or part because
        they reflect unique historic conditions and/or because they continue
        to provide a relevant policy framework for future community growth.
        These Secondary Plans are found in Chapter Six of this Plan. For
        those Secondary Plans that do not have implementing zoning
        by-laws, by-laws will be prepared as expeditiously as possible in
        order for these Plans to be reali zed.



   Policies
   1. Secondary Plans will set the stage for reurbanization of a defined area to
      stimulate and guide development in keeping with the Plan's objectives.
   2. Secondary Plans will generally be prepared, in consultation with the
      community, for areas demonstrating one or more of the following
      characteristics:



                                                                                              ,      r-                                                    S-9
                                                                                                   , I''
          !MPLEM~NIAT!Q~,   MAKING T~I~.G.S. HAPPIN.




                       a) large areas of vacant or underutilized land which would benefit
                          from comprehensive planning to enable suitable development or
                          redevelopment;
                       b) areas targeted for major public or private investment;
                       c) areas where development is occurring, or proposed, at a scale, intensity
                          or character which necessitates reconsideration or reconfiguration of
                          local streets, block plans, public works, open space or other public
                          services or facilities; and
                       d) other growth areas identified in provisions of this Plan, such as Centres,
                          selected Avenues identified by Committees of Council and Regeneration
                          Areas.
                       Where Council has determined that a Secondary Plan is necessary in an
                       area prior to receiving a development application in that area, no amendment
                       to the Zoning By-law permitting large scale development in the area will be
                       made without prior or concurrent adoption of a Secondary Plan, provided that
                       the Secondary Plan is adopted within a reasonable period of time.
               3. Secondary Plans will promote a desired type and form of physical
                  development resulting in highly functional and attractive communities and
                  plan for an appropriate transition in scale and activity between neighbouring
                  districts.
               4. City-building objectives for Secondary Planning areas will identify or indicate
                  the following :
                       a) overall capacity for development in the area, including anticipated
                          population;
                       b) opportunities or constraints posed by unique environmental, economic,
                          heritage, cultural and other features or characteristics;
                       c) affordable housing objectives;
                       d) land use policies for development, redevelopment, intensification and/or
                          infilling;
                       e) urban design objectives, guidelines and parameters;
                       f) necessary infrastructure investment with respect to any aspect of:
                          transportation services, environmental services, community and social
                          facilities, cultural, entertainment and tourism facilities, pedestrian
                          systems, parks and recreation services, or other local or municipal
                          services; and
                       g) where a Secondary Planning area is adjacent to an established
                          neighbourhood or neighbourhoods, new development must respect and
                          reinforce the existing physical character and promote the stability of the
                          established neighbourhoods.

               5. An implementing zoning by-law and/or development permit by-law will be
                  prepared concurrently for new Secondary Plans unless Council determines
                  that development is to proceed by site specific zoning.

IBI GROUP FINAL REPORT

Appendix F – Additional Comments
Received through the Public Consultation
Process
Note: For a full review of all of the public consultation materials prepared as part of the Phase 1 Study, including handouts,
presentations and meeting minutes please see the Etobicoke York Community Planning: Humbertown Secondary Plan Study Area –
Phase One project website here:
http://www1.toronto.ca/wps/portal/contentonly?vgnextoid=f02d8b9d24d56410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD&vgnextchannel=82e352
cc66061410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD




July 16, 2014                                                                                                                    E-2
            ZLZZ
    e
        /   -.-,p
.
Received June 6, 2014:

My concern is traffic at Royal York Court and Royal York Road. It may take 15 minutes and longer to turn left on Royal
York Road. Cars are lined up to exit Royal York Court. According to the "Final Report" document, reference 12 111249
WET 04 OZ, page 23, it states there will be an outbound ramp on Lambeth Road and an inbound ramp on a street
opposite to Strath Humber Court.
Traffic is already congested in this area at rush hours. I believe there is no plan to widen Royal York Road.
Today if we turn left onto Royal York Road then my wait times are:
Normal: 3 minutes
Peak: 8 minutes

Received June 13, 2014:

I would like to make clear the following point, if housing policy remains adamant about 1:1 on-site replacement at
comparable existing unit size, then redevelopment can only be achieved by raising densities to the point where land
values exceed that of the apartment building. Otherwise, more modest redevelopment could place if they were to loosen
the existing protections.
If the City is unwilling to address these two avenues, then these areas will not be redeveloped unless a large developer
was to assemble multiple properties.
It is naive to assume, given the existing site context and policy framework, that any current landlord would ever consider
redevelopment of their sites at 4-, 5- or 6-storeys at 1:1 on-site rental replacement.
In most situations in this study area (sites that are around 15,000 square feet), the economics of redevelopment at 1:1 on-
site replacement only work at densities of 5 to 6 times or greater, which would equate to 8- to 12-storey buildings.

Received June 13, 2014:

To help you and others at City Planning with the Humbertown Secondary Plan Area Study, I prepared a short list of topics
which I believe are relevant. My list might possibly be useful for a working group, or groups, to discuss as part of Phase
1.
List of Suggested Topics for Humber Valley working group and Humbertown Secondary Plan Area Study - Phase
1
Public Art: Consult an art theorist. Creative and inspiring works should be on permanent or rotating display in a public
setting, with recital space. Psychological and scientific research indicates art has direct and indirect community and
economic benefits.
Noise: Keep track of noise. Calibrated sound meters could be used to monitor and map noise levels related to everyday
activities, traffic, and construction activities, to avoid adverse health effects in residents. American National Standards
Institute (ANSI) standards could be used for reference. A recent study around the Toronto Airport indicated significantly
higher than normal health problems in residents around the airport, where planes rattle church windows. What is
appropriate?
Ground Water: Know where the water goes. Runoff water and groundwater flows probably will be affected by
construction of new buildings. A geyser recently erupted during drilling in the Humbertown parking lot. Why?
Ground Radiation: Measure radiation. Building basements near sedimentary bedroom, such as local shale, could
release some radioactivity if the bedrock has particles containing radioactive elements.
Earthquake Protection: Consider earthquake resistance of buildings. Existing buildings appear stable. There was a
small earthquake in Humber Valley in July 2010. There is an active geological fault in Lake Ontario (Clarendon-Lyndon).
Have any lessons been learned from good construction practices in a place like Japan that could be applied in Humber
Valley?
Power Demands: Figure out the power needs of new construction. The Toronto Star recently reported that Bruce
Nuclear reactor tubes are now to be used up to approximately 1/4 longer than expected to satisfy to satisfy the demand
for Ontario's electricity. New sources of electrical power generated within the study area could be considered.
Retrofitting Apartments: Reuse what you have. e.g. Skyline Apartment REIT is retrofitting 40 year old apartment
buildings with energy efficient technology such as the Ontario government's microFIT solar panels (photovoltaic) on roof
tops, energy efficient boilers, water efficient plumbing, and green roofs.
Social Structure: Know how people need to get around in the area. What is the web of life here? Consider asking 100
local volunteers to carry a locator or GPS with them for 15 to 30 days, to get a decent idea of where their physical and
social paths lie, and how they interact, to get a better idea of how the Humber Valley community works.
Green Effect: Know the importance of greenery and include it in a plan. Green areas in a Swedish study were shown to
reduce the crime rate in an adjacent area. (In Japan this psychological green effect was also studied and is traditionally
known as "forest air bathing" and called "shinrin-yoku). A green roof with wild plants on a building might help.
Nature Conservancy: Live alongside nature. The elegant monarch butterfly is suffering from reduced food sources and
loss of habitat (where an animal usually lives). In local green areas, plan milkweed to sustain the monarch. Note that any
large buildings could represent a migration flight path impediment to the Monarch.
Traffic Management: A specific example of the need for local traffic management was presented in a letter to Councillor
Lindsay Luby, who forwarded it on to the City for review. A copy is enclosed.
Letter to Councillor Lindsay Luby:
Re: Traffic and parking conditions on St. George’s and Canterbury Roads
There appears to be an excess of traffic and parking occurring on both St. George’s and Canterbury Roads. An overflow
of cars seems to occur frequently during events at the Kingsway College School and St. George’s Church.
The possibility of excess St. George’s Road traffic to Humbertown was also described and cartographically illustrated by
one of the members of the HVVRA during the council meeting at Etobicoke Civic Centre on September 10, 2013.
This photograph illustrates the kind of traffic and parking problems that are occurring on St. George’s road and also on
Canterbury Road. This situation prevents easy access by service and emergency vehicles, and creates access and
egress problems for residents: this also means you frequently cannot back out of your driveway. I thought you should be
aware of this situation. Perhaps traffic management personnel for Etobicoke should have these problems drawn to their
attention.

Received June 13, 2014:

After consultation with the Board of Royal York Gardens Tenants Association:
1. If there are community consultations, the attending community should be encouraged to ask questions and provide
   comments, rather than being patronized and shouted down by staff and its consultants.
2. Staff’s August deadlines should not take precedence over the community’s ability to participate. Your schedule
   squeezing all community consultation into 3 weeks makes the consultation process a farce.
3. In addressing the community, please obviate the use of planning bureaucratese.
4. At such meetings, do not simply have placard maps etc., but hand out such material to those attending, or at least
   broadcast the website on which the material can be viewed.
5. A major community fear is that the Humbertown plan and the present zoning immediately north of Humbertown will
   provide Elias with precedent to justify destruction of the present low-rise apartments, for replacement by apartments of
   enormous height. Please set out clearly how that can most effectively avoided.
   The consultation meeting was left with the impression that supporting a Phase 2 Secondary Plan would pave the way
   for a developer application to build such enormous replacement buildings. If so, then little more needs to be
   discussed: the community would vehemently oppose a move into a secondary plan.
6. The Planning Department should work directly with the two significant resident associations in the consultation area:
   the HVVRA and the RYGTA. They are very representative and include in-depth experience and expertise.

Received June 15, 2014:

First of all, I want to thank you for your patience hosting the Humbertown Secondary Plan Study meeting. The residents
are a challenging bunch, and it certainly is difficult keeping composure. Whatever the outcome, I hope we can work with
the developers instead of losing this to the OMB.
I do have another concern that relates more with the original proposed shape of the secondary plan. The junction of
Royal York Rd and Dundas St is dangerous for pedestrians (different crossings), cars (“blind” sightlines) and cyclists
(large hill overpass, poorly maintained road, excessive speed of cars). As well, it is unsightly, and presumably very
expensive to maintain. It was built in the 1950s (I believe) and soon it will reach the end of its designed lifespan. Six
Points interchange is currently in the process of being flattened and redeveloped, which is something I hope can happen
here as well.
Once this happens, there is an opportunity to reintegrate the two neighbourhoods, and create a more urban environment
instead of a highway interchange in the middle of a residential neighbourhood. But it also provides the city with the
potential to redevelop land that is currently being used by the interchange on/off ramps. The selling of a piece of this land
could finance the redesign and reconstruction of the intersection.
If indeed this was feasible, should this land be incorporated into the Dundas St. Avenues Plan, this Humbertown
Secondary Plan, or potentially a new site-specific amendment? Do you have any ideas about the future of this
intersection?

Received June 17, 2014:

I’m very concerned about the redevelopment at Humbertown Plaza and the surrounding residential area. I understand
there are plans to redevelop the older buildings on The Kingsway. Please bear in mind that our infrastructure does not
allow for more traffic in Toronto at the current time. Please stall this development until our traffic begins moving again in
Toronto.

Received June 17, 2014:

Hi, I am a resident of Humber Valley Village and am thoroughly worried about condos and apartments being built in the
area. The small rise buildings are suitable for our area since it is a residential and well established area. Large buildings
will cause a traffic concern, transportation issue (not enough buses on route), small roads only a two way road on Royal
York Road. We do not want the area to turn into a downtown. It’s already hard to get out from Royal York Gardens due
to the traffic being heavy. It can take up to 20 minutes to make a left turn from the condominium there. Buses are all
ready full of people; it takes two to three buses to go by before we can get on one.

Received June 17, 2014:

I have some specific traffic concerns in this area. There is a park, school and lots of young children living nearby, lots of
foot traffic. The speed limit is 40km/h; however some cars drive double this limit going towards the Dundas St. ramp.
Can you please advise if this secondary plan will address speeding in the area as its very dangerous at times for
pedestrians and will surely get worse after the redevelopment.
Perhaps speed humps or other options to address this issue could be looked at? Gloria was willing to help and had
mentioned she didn't believe this was possible as zoning prohibits humps. Richard Beck from your team believes this can
be achieved or other solutions can be tabled. Wondering if you could clear this up for me.
The entire street does have the same concerns and i would be happy to canvass for signatures if you feel we need to. Let
me know on this part.
Additionally, with respect to the timing of the secondary plan study, before allowing any further permits, why isn't the city
waiting until the true impact of the Humbertown development stats on local traffic is known?
Currently, only predictions & assumptions have been made on traffic for the Humbertown area. The true impacts would
not be confirmed until the after development is complete. What if the city was wrong with their earlier findings? Shouldn't
the city wait to have all facts confirmed prior to moving forward with such an important study or even allowing further
development?

Received June 17, 2014:

No more high rise development of any kind or this area will become ghetto.

Received June 20, 2014:

I am a resident of Humber Valley Village and understand you are the planner responsible for reviewing the secondary
plan. I have questions and concerns about the significant amount of redevelopment and density that is being added to
our neighbourhood. My questions and concerns revolve principally around safety given the following facts:
  1. Our neighbourhood roads are narrow and there are few sidewalks.
  2. Many children live in the neighbourhood and they are frequently walking or biking on the narrow roads.
  3. Speed has been an issue on certain roads, in particular the Kingsway around Humbertown.
I’d like to understand what consideration you are giving to the pedestrian safety as you review the secondary plan.
Received June 20, 2014:

  1. Do any of the "tools" allow or require an economic impact study on the effect the development has on the area and
     especially the impact on the market value of surrounding residences. One of the main concerns that many seniors
     in the neighbourhood have is that the market value of their house is going to decrease significantly due to the
     development. In essence, what the developers accomplish is transferring the equity that these people have built up
     in their home and take it away from them and that equity goes directly into their development and their profits (they
     are building in the area because they can benefit off of the neighbourhood, get higher unit prices etc.). There should
     be some sort of protective legislation that says that if an economic impact study determines that the houses within a
     certain radius or area will likely decrease in value then the developers should be held accountable to make
     restitution.
  2. Currently the TDSB has stated that the school grounds surrounding HVVJMS can be sold for development. There
     should be some protection that school greenspace should be maintained if development (which will increase
     density in the area) is going to go ahead. Somehow there should be some way that the TDSB can get money from
     the developer as compensation for not selling the greenspace as the residents of the development benefit from the
     greenspace and the developers benefit from the greenspace because it makes their development attractive. It
     would be devastating to the area if both the low rise apartments get the go ahead to redevelop into 6 and 8 storey
     buildings and the HVV grounds get developed into condos/townhouses as well.

Received June 27, 2014:

This is a low density single family neighbourhood that has had a small strip of low rise apartment buildings along The
Kingsway between Humbertown and Anglesey. It is also important to note that all the development that has gone on in
that area has the buildings well set back from the street curb. Up to 80'.
Between where I work and where I live, I have noticed that many of the buildings that have gone up in the last 20-30
years have been set well back from the curb.
  1. Clarica Centre (High Density Commercial High Rise) set 70-80' from the curb of Bloor St.
  2. Montgomery and Bloor (South Side Residential Building) set back 20-40' with grass boulevard
  3. Across from Shoppers Drug Mart (apartment building) set 80' off of the curb
  4. Royal York Gardens (across from Humbertown on Royal York) set 80' off of the Royal York curb
With any development, set backs are one of the most important aspects that must be respected to allow the development
to maintain the integrity of a cosy low density residential neighbourhood.
The second most important aspect is Height. The buildings are currently 3-4 storeys. I would prefer to keep this height
but understand the need for change and for developers to make a decent return on their investment. However, buildings
should not be significantly higher than the top of the mature tree canopy. This continues to maintain the integrity of the
residential neighbourhood.
The third point. The tree canopy should be maintained and allowed to reach a proper full growth height over a 40 year
period. There should be no compromise on any type of trees restricted to containers and reduced growth cycle to 7
years. The trees should be able to reach their full maturity over a 40 year period. There needs to be an ample grow
space in the ground to allow this.
To summarise. My three major points are as follows:
  1. Building set back, minimum 70'
  2. Building height limit to the maximum of a 40 year growth tree that would be surrounding the building
  3. Tree canopy should be able to grow to full height over the 40 year period.
These points must be included in the baseline of all development in this neighbourhood. It will maintain the character and
integrity of our neighbourhood. This will ultimately make any development that is done by a builder become more
attractive.
